options: virtual seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I learned about the evolution of pragmatic theories of implicature.
A deep dive into implicature, lying, other pragmatic theory. Theoretical and empirical readings shed light on patterns within the above.

I've developed a well-rounded understanding of pragmatic reasoning, as inspired by Grice's work. We learned about Q and R principles; negative strengthening; exhaustivity; and scalar implicatures in those with ASD, to name just a few.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I feel like this seminar wouldve been much more engaging and interactive had it been in-person. Zoom for two hours for what boils down to a lecture and not really discussion got very tiring very fast.

Strengths: well-organized; good pacing; Professor Horn was a wonderful professor!

I wonder if for future classes, whether online or not, incorporating multi-media presentations would help keep students engaged with class lectures. I enjoyed classes the most when Professor Horn would play a song to show exhaustivity in action, or even when he made some of our studies relevant to current social-political discussions.
I also wonder if lessening weekly readings or being really explicit about what to read, would help make assignments more meaningful. I found myself more lost when I had to strategically skim-read 4 papers, as opposed to thoroughly reading 2.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Student engagement was low due to seminar length of what is a lecture class doing it online made it easy to zone out of
There were no online-specific learning practices implemented outside of recording the lectures.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Absolutely. This is a fascinating topic, and the class is very well taught.
Always recommend a class with Larry! Truly an experience. You cant be in Linguistics (or ling adjacent) at Yale and not take a class with him
Yes, if you're curious about pragmatics and would enjoy a balance of theoretical and experimental work.
